clusters.title: Japan's Sanae Takaichi secures major party victory in snap election
clusters.neutral_headline: Japan Liberal Democratic Party Wins Election

items.title: Japan's Sanae Takaichi secures major party victory in snap election
items.standfirst: Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's Liberal Democratic Party secured a two-thirds supermajority of the parliament's lower house for the first time since World War II. CBS News foreign correspondent Anna Coren has the latest.
items.content: Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's Liberal Democratic Party secured a two-thirds supermajority of the parliament's lower house for the first time since World War II. CBS News foreign correspondent Anna Coren has the latest.

items.title: Japanese PM after landslide victory: ‘I do not fear any challenges’
items.standfirst: Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi’s coalition has won 352 of the 465 seats in the lower house of Parliament.
items.content: Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi’s coalition has won 352 of the 465 seats in the lower house of Parliament.

items.title: UK borrowing costs rise, then dip, as pressure grows on Starmer; Japan’s Nikkei hits record high after Takaichi’s election win – as it happened
items.standfirst: Rolling coverage of the latest economic and financial newsSanae Takaichi’s conservatives cement power in landslide Japan election winSterling is dropping this morning after the resignation of Morgan McSweeney, Keir Starmer’s chief of staff, increased the pressure on the prime minister.The pound has fallen by half a eurocent to €1.146, the lowest since 22 January.In the UK, political pressure on PM Starmer is mounting which is weighing on UK assetsThe Japanese parliamentary election, held yesterday, saw an overwhelming victory for the Liberal Democratic Party. The party, led by Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi, won two thirds of the seats in the lower house, the best result for a single party since the end of the Second World War.Japanese stocks performed well as Takaichi intends to pursue supportive fiscal policy. Japanese government bond yields edged slightly higher, while the yen gained ground after Japanese Finance Minister Satsuki Katayama reiterated her willingness to preserve the stability of the currency. Continue reading...
items.content: Rolling coverage of the latest economic and financial newsSanae Takaichi’s conservatives cement power in landslide Japan election winSterling is dropping this morning after the resignation of Morgan McSweeney, Keir Starmer’s chief of staff, increased the pressure on the prime minister.The pound has fallen by half a eurocent to €1.146, the lowest since 22 January.In the UK, political pressure on PM Starmer is mounting which is weighing on UK assetsThe Japanese parliamentary election, held yesterday, saw an overwhelming victory for the Liberal Democratic Party. The party, led by Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi, won two thirds of the seats in the lower house, the best result for a single party since the end of the Second World War.Japanese stocks performed well as Takaichi intends to pursue supportive fiscal policy. Japanese government bond yields edged slightly higher, while the yen gained ground after Japanese Finance Minister Satsuki Katayama reiterated her willingness to preserve the stability of the currency. Continue reading...

items.title: Can Japan's Takaichi deliver on economic promises?
items.standfirst: Japanese stocks soared to record highs Monday after Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's election triumph, but experts warned that the country's first woman leader could struggle to keep both voters and markets happy.
items.content: Japanese stocks soared to record highs Monday after Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's election triumph, but experts warned that the country's first woman leader could struggle to keep both voters and markets happy.

items.title: Japan’s Takaichi secures supermajority in landslide election victory
items.standfirst: Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi 's governing party secured a two-thirds supermajority in parliamentary elections, Japanese media reported, citing preliminary results. The landslide victory was due, in large part, to the extraordinary popularity of Japan's first female prime minister, and allows her to pursue a significant conservative shift in Japan’s security, immigration and other policies.
items.content: Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi 's governing party secured a two-thirds supermajority in parliamentary elections, Japanese media reported, citing preliminary results. The landslide victory was due, in large part, to the extraordinary popularity of Japan's first female prime minister, and allows her to pursue a significant conservative shift in Japan’s security, immigration and other policies.

items.title: Japan's Takaichi to pursue conservative agenda after election landslide
items.standfirst: Japan's first female Prime Minister, Sanae Takaichi, brought the ruling Liberal Democratic Party its biggest-ever electoral victory, fueling her ambitions to pursue to a political agenda which she says could "split public opinion."
items.content: Japan's first female Prime Minister, Sanae Takaichi, brought the ruling Liberal Democratic Party its biggest-ever electoral victory, fueling her ambitions to pursue to a political agenda which she says could "split public opinion." (Image credit: Keisuke Hosojima)

items.title: Japanese shares hit record high as Sanae Takaichi wins landslide election victory
items.standfirst: Prime minister’s Liberal Democratic party to be pressed on promised tax cuts and fiscal stimulus plansBusiness live – latest updatesJapan’s stock market has hit a record high after Sanae Takaichi’s Liberal Democratic party (LDP) secured a comprehensive victory in Sunday’s election.The LDP won 316 of the 465 seats in the country’s lower house – the first time a single party has secured two-thirds of the chamber since the establishment of Japan’s parliament in 1947. Continue reading...
items.content: Prime minister’s Liberal Democratic party to be pressed on promised tax cuts and fiscal stimulus plansBusiness live – latest updatesJapan’s stock market has hit a record high after Sanae Takaichi’s Liberal Democratic party (LDP) secured a comprehensive victory in Sunday’s election.The LDP won 316 of the 465 seats in the country’s lower house – the first time a single party has secured two-thirds of the chamber since the establishment of Japan’s parliament in 1947. Continue reading...

items.title: Jimmy Lai: will Hong Kong media tycoon die in jail? – The Latest
items.standfirst: The media mogul and prominent pro-democracy activist Jimmy Lai has been sentenced to 20 years in prison in Hong Kong for national security offences. His family has described the sentence as ‘heartbreakingly cruel’, given the 78-year-old’s declining health. Lai was convicted in December on charges of sedition and conspiracy to collude with foreign forces, after pleading not guilty to all charges. Lucy Hough speaks to the Guardian’s senior China correspondent, Amy Hawkins – watch on YouTube Continue reading...
items.content: The media mogul and prominent pro-democracy activist Jimmy Lai has been sentenced to 20 years in prison in Hong Kong for national security offences. His family has described the sentence as ‘heartbreakingly cruel’, given the 78-year-old’s declining health. Lai was convicted in December on charges of sedition and conspiracy to collude with foreign forces, after pleading not guilty to all charges. Lucy Hough speaks to the Guardian’s senior China correspondent, Amy Hawkins – watch on YouTube Continue reading...

items.title: Hong Kong: Pro-democracy activist Jimmy Lai sentenced to 20 years in prison
items.standfirst: On February 9, #HongKong pro-democracy figure Jimmy #Lai, 78, was sentenced to 20 years in prison for collusion with foreign forces and publishing seditious material after a brief hearing. A landmark national security case that has sparked global condemnation over #Beijing’s tightening grip on Hong Kong’s freedoms.
items.content: On February 9, #HongKong pro-democracy figure Jimmy #Lai, 78, was sentenced to 20 years in prison for collusion with foreign forces and publishing seditious material after a brief hearing. items.title: Jimmy Lai, Hong Kong pro-democracy figure, sentenced to 20 years in prison
items.standfirst: Family of media tycoon say he will ‘die a martyr behind bars’ amid widespread criticism from press freedom groupsJimmy Lai, the media mogul and prominent pro-democracy activist, has been sentenced to 20 years in prison in Hong Kong for national security offences, a punishment his daughter said could mean “he will die a martyr behind bars”.Claire Lai said the sentence was “heartbreakingly cruel” given her 78-year-old father’s declining health, while her brother Sebastien Lai called the sentence “draconian” and “devastating”. Continue reading...

items.title: Prominent Venezuelan opposition politician detained hours after release
items.standfirst: Prosecutor claims Juan Pablo Guanipa was re-arrested due to non-compliance with terms of releaseOne of Venezuela’s most prominent opposition politicians, Juan Pablo Guanipa, has been detained by security forces just hours after being released from prison, as the South American country’s leaders sent mixed signals about their commitment to political reform after Nicolás Maduro’s downfall.Guanipa, who is a close ally of the Nobel laureate María Corina Machado, emerged from nearly nine months’ detention on Sunday – one of at least 35 political prisoners to be freed over the course of the day. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Israel paves way for further settlement expansion in occupied West Bank
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Expands Control Over West Bank

items.title: Israel paves way for further settlement expansion in occupied West Bank
items.standfirst: Israel's security cabinet approved a series of measures on Sunday set to deepen Israeli control over the occupied West Bank, paving the way for further settlement expansion in the Palestinian territory. The measures, announced by Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich and Defence Minister Israel Katz, include the removal of decades-old regulations barring Jewish citizens from purchasing land in the West Bank, according to a joint statement by the two ministers.
items.content: Israel's security cabinet approved a series of measures on Sunday set to deepen Israeli control over the occupied West Bank, paving the way for further settlement expansion in the Palestinian territory. The measures, announced by Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich and Defence Minister Israel Katz, include the removal of decades-old regulations barring Jewish citizens from purchasing land in the West Bank, according to a joint statement by the two ministers.

items.title: Israeli plans deepen de facto annexation of occupied West Bank
items.standfirst: Israel approves plans to expand its power across the West Bank, making it easier to seize Palestinian land illegally.
items.content: Israel approves plans to expand its power across the West Bank, making it easier to seize Palestinian land illegally.

items.title: Israel tightens grip on occupied West Bank with governance changes
items.standfirst: Palestinians say Israeli changes to occupied West Bank governance essentially legalise settlements.
items.content: Palestinians say Israeli changes to occupied West Bank governance essentially legalise settlements.

items.title: Palestinians say new Israeli measures in West Bank amount to de facto annexation
items.standfirst: The measures aim to increase Israeli control over the occupied West Bank in terms of property law, planning, licensing and enforcement.
items.content: The measures aim to increase Israeli control over the occupied West Bank in terms of property law, planning, licensing and enforcement.

items.title: Arab states condemn Israel as it expands control over occupied West Bank
items.standfirst: Saudi Arabia and other regional states on Monday condemned Israel's measures to extend its control over the occupied West Bank. Israel announced Sunday evening that its security cabinet had approved a series of decisions that would make it easier for settlers to buy land in the Palestinian territory occupied by Israel since 1967.
items.content: Saudi Arabia and other regional states on Monday condemned Israel's measures to extend its control over the occupied West Bank. Israel announced Sunday evening that its security cabinet had approved a series of decisions that would make it easier for settlers to buy land in the Palestinian territory occupied by Israel since 1967.

items.title: Israel's security cabinet approves measures to strengthen control over the West Bank
items.standfirst: Israel ’s security cabinet on Sunday approved measures that aim to deepen Israeli control over the occupied West Bank and weaken the already limited powers of the Palestinian Authority. The office of far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich in a statement announced the decisions that would make it easier for Jewish settlers to force Palestinians to give up land, adding that “we will continue to bury the idea of a Palestinian state.”
items.content: Israel ’s security cabinet on Sunday approved measures that aim to deepen Israeli control over the occupied West Bank and weaken the already limited powers of the Palestinian Authority. The office of far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich in a statement announced the decisions that would make it easier for Jewish settlers to force Palestinians to give up land, adding that “we will continue to bury the idea of a Palestinian state.”

items.title: 53 people dead or missing after migrant boat capsizes in Mediterranean
items.standfirst: Only two survivors rescued after boat overturned off Libyan coast, UN migration agency saysFifty-three people are dead or missing after a boat capsized in the Mediterranean Sea off the Libyan coast, the UN migration agency said on Monday. Only two survivors were rescued.The International Organization for Migration said the boat overturned north of Zuwara on Friday, in the latest disaster involving people attempting the perilous Mediterranean crossing in the hope of reaching Europe. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Man who killed 51 Muslim worshippers blames guilty plea on prison 'conditions'
clusters.neutral_headline: Christchurch gunman seeks to appeal convictions and withdraw guilty plea

items.title: Man who killed 51 Muslim worshippers blames guilty plea on prison 'conditions'
items.standfirst: A white supremacist who killed 51 Muslim worshippers at two mosques in New Zealand in 2019 said on Monday that he was irrational when he pleaded guilty, as he sought to ⁠overturn his conviction.
items.content: A white supremacist who killed 51 Muslim worshippers at two mosques in New Zealand in 2019 said on Monday that he was irrational when he pleaded guilty, as he sought to ⁠overturn his conviction.

items.title: Christchurch gunman seeks to appeal convictions and withdraw guilty plea
items.standfirst: Australian white supremacist tells NZ court he was suffering from ‘nervous exhaustion’ when he entered his guilty plea in March 2020 The Australian white supremacist who murdered 51 Muslim worshippers at two mosques in Christchurch in 2019, in the worst mass shooting in the New Zealand’s history, has asked a court to discard his guilty pleas, claiming harsh prison conditions had affected his mental health and compelled him to admit to the crimes.Brenton Tarrant pleaded guilty in March 2020 to 51 counts of murder, 40 counts of attempted murder and a terrorism charge, after initially saying he would defend the charges. In August 2020, Tarrant became the first person in New Zealand under current laws to be sentenced to life in prison without the chance of ever walking free. Continue reading...
items.content: Australian white supremacist tells NZ court he was suffering from ‘nervous exhaustion’ when he entered his guilty plea in March 2020 The Australian white supremacist who murdered 51 Muslim worshippers at two mosques in Christchurch in 2019, in the worst mass shooting in the New Zealand’s history, has asked a court to discard his guilty pleas, claiming harsh prison conditions had affected his mental health and compelled him to admit to the crimes.Brenton Tarrant pleaded guilty in March 2020 to 51 counts of murder, 40 counts of attempted murder and a terrorism charge, after initially saying he would defend the charges. In August 2020, Tarrant became the first person in New Zealand under current laws to be sentenced to life in prison without the chance of ever walking free. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Australian white supremacist pleaded guilty in 2020
He now claims harsh prison conditions affected his mental health
He seeks to overturn his conviction and withdraw guilty plea
He was sentenced to life in prison without parole
He pleaded guilty to 51 counts of murder and terrorism
